It is a signaling protocol used to create and control multimedia sessions with two or more participants in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS). SIP was designed to provide a signaling and call setup protocol for IP-based communications, supporting call processing functions and features present in the public switched telephone network (PSTN). It has been extended for video conferencing, streaming media distribution, instant messaging, presence information, file transfer, Internet fax, and online games. Additionally, SIP-I, or the Session Initiation Protocol with encapsulated ISUP, is a protocol used to create, modify, and terminate communication sessions based on ISUP using SIP and IP networks. This protocol is used for services such as voice, video telephony, fax, and data. The NG9-1-1 vision relies on SIP to deliver voice, video, text, and data "calls" to the PSAP, and it is a key element in the IMS framework.
